title: Easy Ways to Type Symbols & Special Characters on Your Keyboard

steps.title: Make sure NumLock is on.
steps.content: Make sure NumLock is on. If you have a 10-digit keypad to the right of your keyboard, you'll also see a "NumLock" key that you can press to toggle NumLock on or off. You might need to press the "Fn" key to toggle NumLock. The key will either light up or show on-screen if NumLock is on or off.

steps.title: Press and hold Alt (Windows) or ⌥ Opt (Mac).
steps.content: Press and hold Alt (Windows) or ⌥ Opt (Mac). Keep holding it as you enter the code.

steps.title: Enter the code with the keypad.
steps.content: Enter the code with the keypad. You can use the cheat sheets above to find the ALT code that you're looking for. If you're using a Windows computer, you must use the 10-digit keypad to the right of your keyboard; using the row of numbers at the top of your keyboard will not work for the ALT codes. This rule doesn't apply to Macs. Enter any "0"s that appear in the code. For example, Alt + 0128 enters the symbol for Euros on Windows; press ⇧ Shift + ⌥ Opt + 2 for the same symbol on Mac. For example, Alt + 227 enters the Pi symbol on Windows; press ⌥ Opt + P on Mac.

steps.title: Release any keys you're holding down.
steps.content: Release any keys you're holding down. On Windows, release Alt and the symbol will be inserted where your cursor is. On Mac, release Opt (maybe Shift as well if you had to hold that down for the ALT code), and the symbol will appear where your cursor is.

steps.title: Open the Character Map.
steps.content: Open the Character Map. You can find it by opening the Start menu and searching for "Character Map".

steps.title: Select a common font.
steps.content: Select a common font. Click the "Font" drop-down menu at the top of the Character Map window, then click a commonly used font (e.g., Arial ) in the drop-down menu. The reason you need to do this is that less commonly used fonts include different symbols which aren't compatible with some programs.

steps.title: Find the symbol you want to type.
steps.content: Find the symbol you want to type. Scroll through the list of symbols until you find the one you want to use.

steps.title: Select the symbol.
steps.content: Select the symbol. Click the symbol once to select it. You should see the symbol enlarge slightly.

steps.title: Click Select.
steps.content: Click Select . It's at the bottom of the window. The symbol will be added to the "Characters to copy" text field.

steps.title: Click Copy.
steps.content: Click Copy . You'll find this in the lower-right corner of the window. Doing so copies the symbol to your clipboard.

steps.title: Paste the symbol into a document.
steps.content: Paste the symbol into a document. Once you've copied your symbol, open a text field or document, then press Ctrl + V to paste in the symbol.

steps.title: Move your cursor to a spot for your symbol.
steps.content: Move your cursor to a spot for your symbol. Click the spot in the document or text field in which you want to type the symbol.

steps.title: Click Edit.
steps.content: Click Edit . It's a menu item at the top of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear. Alternatively, press Fn + E (or just Fn , depending on the app you're using and/or any custom keyboard shortcuts you may have set) and skip the next step.

steps.title: Click Emoji & Symbols.
steps.content: Click Emoji & Symbols . This is near the bottom of the drop-down menu. Doing so opens the Emoji & Symbols window.

steps.title: Select a symbol category.
steps.content: Select a symbol category. You'll see different categories displayed along the top or bottom of the Character Viewer window. The clock icon contains emojis and symbols that you've recently used. [1] X Research source If you can't easily find your symbol, use Expanded View to help you. Click the keyboard icon in the top right corner to make the Character Viewer bigger.

steps.title: Find the symbol you want to use.
steps.content: Find the symbol you want to use. Look through the list of symbols (scrolling down if necessary) until you find the one you want to type.

steps.title: Double-click your symbol.
steps.content: Double-click your symbol. This will add the symbol to the text field or document in which your cursor is located. You can also customize this Character Viewer so you can see specific categories before others. To do this, make sure the Character Viewer is expanded (click the keyboard icon), then click ••• > Customize List , and then select and deselect categories that you want to see or hide. Click Done when you're finished.

steps.title: Open a document or text field.
steps.content: Open a document or text field. Tap the app in which you want to type a symbol, then select a conversation or document if necessary before proceeding.

steps.title: Select a spot for your symbol.
steps.content: Select a spot for your symbol. In order to bring up your iPhone's keyboard, you'll have to tap a text field or a space in your selected document (if necessary). If you're editing a document, make sure the cursor is in the space in which you want to type the symbol.

steps.title: Tap 123.
steps.content: Tap 123 . It's in the lower-left side of the screen. Doing so switches your keyboard to display numbers.

steps.title: Tap #+=.
steps.content: Tap #+= . It's in the lower-left side of the window. Your keyboard will now display symbols.

steps.title: Select a symbol.
steps.content: Select a symbol. Tap the symbol you want to type to add it to your selected text box or document location. If you don't see the symbol you want to type, try lightly tapping and holding a symbol to see variations of it. For example, tapping and holding the question mark will prompt a menu with an upside-down question mark to appear. You can type a symbol from this menu by sliding your finger up to select it and then releasing your finger. You can also easily add accents to characters by long-tapping on the un-accented version of the letter and choosing the accent from the menu that pops up. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Open a document or text field.
steps.content: Open a document or text field. In order to bring up your Android's keyboard, you'll need to open an app or a document which has a text field in which you can type information.

steps.title: Select a spot for your symbol.
steps.content: Select a spot for your symbol. Find the place in which you want to type your symbol, then tap it. For example, if you want to add your symbol to a text message, you would open your Android's Messages app, select a contact or conversation, and then tap the text field at the bottom of the screen. If you're editing a document, make sure the cursor is in the space in which you want to type the symbol.

steps.title: Tap ?123.
steps.content: Tap ?123 . It's in the lower-left side of the screen. Doing so switches the keyboard to display symbols and numbers instead of letters. On a Samsung Keyboard, you'll tap !#1 here.

steps.title: Look for your symbol.
steps.content: Look for your symbol. Find the symbol you want to type in the keyboard. If you don't see the symbol you want to type, try long-pressing a symbol to see variations of it. For example, tapping and holding the question mark will prompt a menu with an upside-down question mark to appear. This will not work on the Samsung Keyboard.

steps.title: Open the additional symbols page if necessary.
steps.content: Open the additional symbols page if necessary. If you can't find the symbol you want to type, tap =\< in the lower-left side of the keyboard to open the second page of symbols. On the Samsung Keyboard, you'll instead tap 1/2 to open the second page.

steps.title: Select a symbol.
steps.content: Select a symbol. Tap the symbol you want to type to add it to the text box. If you're selecting a symbol from the long-press menu, long-press the symbol for which you want to use the menu, then slide your finger up and left or right to select the necessary symbol and release your finger to type the symbol.

steps.title: Type the code for your symbol.
steps.content: Type the code for your symbol. For example, the code for the dollar sign is "0024." Not every software, including Microsoft PowerPoint, will convert Unicode symbols. In that case, use ALT codes or the Character Map .

steps.title: Press Alt+X.
steps.content: Press Alt + X . Once you enter 0024 + Alt + X , the dollar sign will appear in the place of your code. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Enable Unicode Hex Input.
steps.content: Enable Unicode Hex Input. By default, your keyboard will not work with Unicode characters, so you have to enable it first. To do this, go to Apple menu > System Settings > Keyboard and click Edit next to "Input Sources." Click + in the bottom left corner of the pop-up window and select "Unicode Hex Input" from the list. Click Add and Done to close the keyboard input window.

steps.title: Navigate to where you want to add symbols and change your keyboard input.
steps.content: Navigate to where you want to add symbols and change your keyboard input. Click the language code symbol in the menu bar at the top of the screen (looks like a rectangle with “US” inside it when it’s set to the standard US keyboard) and select the “Unicode Hex Input” option.

steps.title: Enter the Unicode text while pressing ⌥ Opt.
steps.content: Enter the Unicode text while pressing ⌥ Opt . There are a lot of different codes that you can use, so it might be easier to use the Character Viewer . When you release the Opt key, you'll see the symbol replace the code. For example, press ⌥ Opt + D83DDEA0 for an icon of a cable car. [4] X Research source
